title: Ability to 'save' a stage/venue layer for easy reuse in a new project
Remove unused normalized tables from schema
description:
## Summary
The database schema defines several normalized tables (set_pieces, annotations, instruments, hanging_positions, project_history) that are not being used. All project data is actually stored as a JSONB blob in the projects.layers column, which is the correct approach for this application.

## Problem
- Schema has 5 unused tables that add cognitive overhead
- New developers may be confused about which approach to use
- Schema and implementation are misaligned
- Drizzle migrations include unused table definitions

## Evidence
Looking at actual database data, the projects.layers JSONB column contains:
```json
{
  "shapes": [...],
  "setPieces": [],
  "annotations": [],
  "instruments": [...],
  "hangingPositions": []
}
```

The SyncManager in src/lib/sync/manager.svelte.ts serializes all store data into this single layers blob.

## Tables to Remove
1. `set_pieces` (src/lib/db/schema.ts:94-106)
2. `annotations` (src/lib/db/schema.ts:111-121)
3. `instruments` (src/lib/db/schema.ts:64-89)
4. `hanging_positions` (src/lib/db/schema.ts:46-59)
5. `project_history` (src/lib/db/schema.ts:126-133)

## Why JSONB is Correct
- Project-centric operations (load/save entire plots)
- Simpler undo/redo (snapshot entire state)
- Easier offline sync (one blob vs multi-table transactions)
- Adequate scale (typical plot is ~100KB)

## Implementation Steps
1. Create Drizzle migration to DROP unused tables
2. Remove table definitions from src/lib/db/schema.ts
3. Remove unused TypeScript type exports
4. Update any imports that reference removed tables
5. Consider adding GIN index on projects.layers for future search needs

## Testing
- Verify existing projects still load correctly
- Verify new projects can be created and saved
- Run full test suite
close_reason: Removed 5 unused normalized tables (hanging_positions, instruments, set_pieces, annotations, project_history) from schema. All project data correctly stored in projects.layers JSONB column. Migration created and tested.

description: Welcome to Bits UI, a collection of headless component primitives for Svelte 5 that prioritizes developer experience, accessibility, and flexibility. This guide will help you quickly integrate Bits UI into your Svelte application. Installation Install bits using your preferred package manager. npm install bits-ui Basic Usage After installation, you can import and use Bits UI components in your Svelte files. Here's a simple example using the Accordion component. Item 1 Title This is the collapsible content for this section. Item 2 Title This is the collapsible content for this section. Adding Styles Bits UI components are headless by design, meaning they ship with minimal styling. This gives you complete control over the appearance of your components. Each component that renders an HTML element exposes a class prop and style prop that you can use to apply styles to the element. Styling with TailwindCSS or UnoCSS If you're using a CSS framework like TailwindCSS or UnoCSS, you can pass the classes directly to the components: Tailwind-styled Accordion This accordion is styled using Tailwind CSS classes. Styling with Data Attributes Each Bits UI component applies specific data attributes to the underlying HTML elements. You can use these attributes to target components in your global styles: Check the API Reference for each component to determine its data attributes Use those attributes in your CSS selectors +layout.svelte Click me app.css [data-button-root] { height: 3rem; width: 100%; background-color: #3182ce; color: white; border-radius: 0.375rem; padding: 0.5rem 1rem; font-weight: 500; } [data-button-root]:hover { background-color: #2c5282; } With this approach, every Button.Root component will have these styles applied to it automatically.
